title: Jupyter Notebooks
content:
Why Using Jupyter Notebooks?     Jupyter Notebooks is a powerful way to write and iterate on your Python code for data analysis. It is free and open-source; it provides an opportunity to combine software code, computational output, explanatory text and multimedia resources in a single document.
   Installation      How To Use

title: Installation
content:
To install Jupyter Notebooks     The fastest way to install Jupyter Notebooks (assuming you have Python3 already installed), is to run
pip3 install jupyter If you need more information how to install Jupyter, please follow this link
Getting Started With Jupyter Notebooks     Run the following command to open up the application:
jupyter notebook You will see the application open in your default browser using the following address: http://localhost:8888
A more detailed guide on how to use Jupyter notebooks and how to work with them, can be found here

title: How To Use
content:
How to test sample notebooks using Jupyter Notebooks?       Download the notebooks source code after installing Jupyter on your computer. To be able to perform estimations, download full repositories with Monte Carlo Simulation and Linear Regression sample code.
  Once the sample source code repository is downloaded to the local environment, proceed with the following command to start Jupyter notebooks locally:
  jupyter notebook Default browser will launch Jupyter Labs. Navigate to recently downloaded repository with notebooks. Jupyter notebooks have .ipynb extension. Open the one you’d like to try and click Run for every cell to get the results. Most functions and calls are annotated and explain their role within the notebook.  Jupyter Notebooks are unique in a way that after making every cell Run , there can be expected an output.

title: Monte Carlo Simulation
content: When To Use     Input     Output     Dice Roll Concept     Based on Confidence     Based on Historical Data

title: Linear Regression
content: How to Use     When to Use     Input     Output     Single Regression     Multiple Regression
